subtitle: From Mid UI to Product Design Lead: Building Enterprise Software in a Startup

contentBlocks.quote: How did I get here? This definitely wasn't in the job description.
contentBlocks.context: Seven months in, I found myself presenting product architecture to engineers, making strategic decisions about what shipped next. No product manager. No prior product design experience. Just me, a backend engineer, and a platform that needed to exist.

blocks.text: The marketing team was flying blind. Campaign decisions happened in spreadsheets updated when time allowed. By the time they knew something wasn't working, they'd already spent thousands. CEO saw the inefficiency: fragmented data, manual workflows and no unified visibility.

CEO:
Create a unified platform for marketing data so we can have more effective spendings and support the 50% projected customer growth

"Channels. Campaigns. Leads.
Unify the data. Make it work."

That was the product spec → 3 section names and a direction.
No feature list. No MVP definition. No user stories. Just trust,autonomy, and 18 months.

The team:
→ 1 Backend Lead > Technical Stak
→ 1 Frontend > +8hrs away
→ Me (Mid UI) > Design + research + QA
→ Roles I absorved > PM, Marketing contactperson, documentation lead

The challenge:
Turn 3 words into a problem-solving product.

Context: Month 2-3 → Pulled off for urgent 2-week project (different stack)

items: 14,000 customers → +10,000 planned growth
Manual data entry across 6+ touchpoints + no visibility between teams
Social Media complaints manually redirected to customer support
No tools to track campaign ROI in real-time
No component libraries, no design patterns, no brand, no precedents
No PM, no UX department
JavaFX (very little documentation available)
8-hour timezone gap with Front-end
Front-end onboarded month 3 with only 1 approved screen
Async-only collaboration
CEO's priority: results, not process

blocks.text: I was hired as a UI designer. But one month in, faced with three section names, no feature definitions, and a backend engineer who also needed directions... someone had to answer:
What actually goes in "Campaigns"? How deep does each section go? What is v1?  and v2? Who decides all this?

columns.heading: The Shift: Becoming Co-Owners

blocks.text:
Backend Lead and I became de facto co-owners, not by choice, but by necessity. No one else was defining scope.
We operated as a hub: each handled our technical domains, but co-owned everything strategic.

items: Backend Lead → All technical architecture, data models, APIs
Me → Design, research, specs, QA
Marketing Lead → provided user validation and domain knowledge (to me)
CEO → received results-based check-ins (from both of us)

columns.alt: Decision framework: User needs → Marketing Lead | Feasibility → Backend Lead | Design approach → Me | Strategic buy-in → Backend + Me together
columns.caption: Co-product ownership model: separate technical domains, shared strategic decisions

columns.heading: Why This Worked

blocks.text:
Backend had the CEO's ear. Rather than compete for access, I leveraged that relationship. Our co-owned decisions had technical and UX backing when presented upward.
We made product decisions by combining both perspectives: I'd propose features based on user pain points. They'd reality-check it against data availability and technical feasibility. Some ideas died there. The ones that survived both filters became the roadmap.

contentBlocks.title: Key Learning: Partnership over Hierarchy
contentBlocks.insight: The strongest validation came from daily collaborators, not executives.
contentBlocks.result: We built the product specs Through design and iteration. Each step was validated.

blocks.text:
Around month 5, during validation with Marketing, I discovered Social Media manager's work was being overtaken by dealing with compaints arriving via Social Media:

The broken flow

items: Customer complains via Facebook DM
Social media team manually copies conversation and emails to Customer Support
Support manually looks up customer in CRM
Ticket created, response sent back via email
Social team manually responds on Facebook

blocks.text: I mapped the entire workflow. Identified the bottleneck. Proposed direct integration:
FB DM → automated ID capture → CRM match → auto-ticket creation

Pitched it to Backend. They confirmed API feasibility and assessed data structure requirements. We added it to roadmap together and presented it as a co-owned feature to the CEO.
After internal demo, it became the #1 requested feature.
I didn't have authority. I didn't have years of product experience. But I had access to users, curiosity about their problems, and a partner willing to build solutions with me.
